column2: WELL, I catched my breath and most fainted.

column2: Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that!
column3: Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that!

column2: But it warn't no time to be sentimentering.
column3: But it warn't no time to be sentimentering.

column2: We'd _got_ to find that boat nowhad to have it for ourselves.

column2: So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, tooseemed a week before we got to the stern.

column2: No sign of a boat.

column2: Jim said he didn't believe he could go any furtherso scared he hadn't hardly any strength left, he said.

column2: But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure.

column2: So on we prowled again.

column2: We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water.
column3: We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water.

column2: When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door there was the skiff, sure enough!
column3: When we got pretty close to the cross hall door there was the skiff, sure enough!

column2: I could just barely see her.

column2: I felt ever so thankful.

column2: In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened.

column3: Heave that blame lantern out o' sight, Bill!

column2: The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me.
column3: The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me.

column2: I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
column3: I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!

column2: We didn't touch an oar, and we didn't speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe.
column3: We didn't touch an oar, and we didn't speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe.

column2: We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
column3: We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.

column2: When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.

column2: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.
column3: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.

column2: Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the menI reckon I hadn't had time to before.
column3: Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the men  I reckon I hadn't had time to before.

column2: I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix.
column3: I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix.

column2: I says to myself, there ain't no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it?
column3: I says to myself, there ain't no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it?

column2: So says I to Jim:
column3: So says I to Jim:

column2: The first light we see we'll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it's a good hiding-place for you and the skiff, and then I'll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.
column3: The first light we see we'll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it's a good hiding place for you and the skiff, and then I'll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.

column2: But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever.
column3: But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever.

column2: The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon.
column3: The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon.

column2: We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.
column3: We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.

column2: After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by and by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
column3: After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by and by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.

column2: It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again.
column3: It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again.

column2: We seen a light now away down to the right, on shore.

column2: So I said I would go for it.
column3: So I said I would go for it.

column2: The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck.
column3: The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck.

column2: We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light.
column3: We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light.

column2: I skimmed around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and by and by I found him roosting on the bitts forward, with his head down between his knees.

column2: I ain't as rich as old Jim Hornback, and I can't be so blame' generous and good to Tom, Dick, and Harry as what he is, and slam around money the way he does; but I've told him a many a time 't I wouldn't trade places with him; for, says I, a sailor's life's the life for me, and I'm derned if _I'd_ live two mile out o' town, where there ain't nothing ever goin' on, not for all his spondulicks and as much more on top of it.

She was a visiting there at Booth's Landing, and just in the edge of the evening she started over with her nigger woman in the horse ferry to stay all night at her friend's house, Miss What you may call her I disremember her name  and they lost their steering oar, and swung around and went a floating down, stern first, about two mile, and saddle baggsed on the wreck, and the ferryman and the nigger woman and the horses was all lost, but Miss Hooker she made a grab and got aboard the wreck.

column2: Well, about an hour after dark we come along down in our trading-scow, and it was so dark we didn't notice the wreck till we was right on it; and so _we_ saddle-baggsed; but all of us was saved but Bill Whippleand oh, he _was_ the best cretur!I most wish 't it had been me, I do."

column2: Looky here, you break for that light over yonder-way, and turn out west when you git there, and about a quarter of a mile out you'll come to the tavern; tell 'em to dart you out to Jim Hornback's, and he'll foot the bill.

column2: I struck for the light, but as soon as he turned the corner I went back and got into my skiff and bailed her out, and then pulled up shore in the easy water about six hundred yards, and tucked myself in among some woodboats; for I couldn't rest easy till I could see the ferryboat start.

column2: But take it all around, I was feeling ruther comfortable on accounts of taking all this trouble for that gang, for not many would a done it.

column2: I wished the widow knowed about it.

column2: I judged she would be proud of me for helping these rapscallions, because rapscallions and dead beats is the kind the widow and good people takes the most interest in.

column2: Well, before long here comes the wreck, dim and dusky, sliding along down!

column2: A kind of cold shiver went through me, and then I struck out for her.

column2: She was very deep, and I see in a minute there warn't much chance for anybody being alive in her.

column2: I pulled all around her and hollered a little, but there wasn't any answer; all dead still.

column2: I felt a little bit heavy-hearted about the gang, but not much, for I reckoned if they could stand it I could.

column2: Then here comes the ferryboat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down-stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye-reach I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker's remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferryboat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a-booming down the river.
column3: Then here comes the ferryboat; so I shoved for the middle of the river on a long down stream slant; and when I judged I was out of eye reach I laid on my oars, and looked back and see her go and smell around the wreck for Miss Hooker's remainders, because the captain would know her uncle Hornback would want them; and then pretty soon the ferryboat give it up and went for the shore, and I laid into my work and went a booming down the river.

column2: It did seem a powerful long time before Jim's light showed up; and when it did show it looked like it was a thousand mile off.
column3: It did seem a powerful long time before Jim's light showed up; and when it did show it looked like it was a thousand mile off.

column2: By the time I got there the sky was beginning to get a little gray in the east; so we struck for an island, and hid the raft, and sunk the skiff, and turned in and slept like dead people.
